Award.AwardTitle: SM: Arithmetic Groups and Their Applications in Combinatorics, Geometry and Topology
Award.AbstractNarration:
A workshop ``Arithmetic Groups and Their Applications in Combinatorics, Geometry and Topology" will be held April 15-18 on the campus of the University of Virginia in Charlottesville. The scientific program of the workshop will be composed of lectures delivered by the leading experts in the area from the US, Brazil, France and Israel, and will highlight the most significant results obtained in the last few years. Special attention will be given to such topics as the analysis of structural properties of arithmetic groups (virtual positivity of the first Betti number, congruence subgroup problem, bounded generation), their applications in algebraic geometry (fake projective planes and fake versions of other important algebraic varieties), in differential geometry and topology (hyperbolic 3-manifolds, isospectral locally symmetric
spaces) and in combinatorics (construction of expanders).

Arithmetic groups are special groups whose elements are matrices with integral entries. This notion, which can be traced back to the work of Gauss on integral quadratic form, plays a crucial role in many areas of mathematics including algebra and various parts of number theory (e.g., the theory of automorphic forms). In recent years, new applications of the theory of arithmetic groups have emerged in algebraic and differential geometry, Lie theory and combinatorics. The workshop will showcase important results involving arithmetic groups. The focus will be placed on making the methods of the theory of arithmetic groups accessible to researchers, particularly young ones, working in a variety of areas.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The workshop ``Arithmetic Groups and Their Applications in Combinatorics, Geometry and Topology'' was held April 15-18 on the grounds of the University of Virginia. It was organized by Mikhail Ershov and Andrei Rapinchuk (both from the Department of Mathematics at UVA). The funding was provided by the Department of Mathematics and the Institute of Mathematical Sciences (UVA) and the National Science Foundation (grant DMS-1034750).

The focus of the workshop was on the theory of arithmetic groups. The notion of an arithmetic group can be traced back to the work of Gauss on integral quadratic forms. Later, finite index subgroups of SL_2(Z) played a prominent role in the development of the classical theory of automorphic forms (Fricke, Klein, Poincare) and its generalizations. The foundations of the theory of arithmetic subgroups of general algebraic groups were laid by Borel, Harish-Chandra and Serre in the 1960s. Since then various aspects of the theory of arithmetic groups have been the subject of very active research marked by numerous connections to other areas of mathematics such as number theory, combinatorics, geometry and topology, and others.

The recent highlights in the theory of arithmetic groups include deep  results about the actions of arithmetic groups on homogeneous spaces, new applications of  the volume formula, and analysis  of  weakly commensurable arithmetic groups that has led to new results on isospectral locally symmetric spaces.  At the same time, many results rooted in the theory of arithmetic groups have been extended to more general groups. In particular, property (T) of Kazhdan was established for the elementary subgroups of Chevalley groups over arbitrary finitely generated commutative rings, which can be used for various constructions of expander graphs. Furthermore, some fundamental properties of higher rank arithmetic groups (superrigidity, normal subgroup property etc.) were extended to other classes of groups, e.g. Kac-Moody groups.

The mission of the workshop was to survey most of these and many other important results in the theory of arithmetic groups obtained in the  last five years and discuss some open problems and potential applications. The workshop was attended by more than 40 mathematicians from the US and other countries (Brazil, Canada, France and  Israel), including graduate students from UVA and 10 graduate students from other schools (Austin, Chicago, Michigan, Princeton, Yale). It should be noted that the workshop brought together mathematicians working in different areas, hence helped to make the results and methods of the subject accessible to researchers working in related areas and promote further collaboration.

The scientific program of the workshop featured 11 talks, each 45 min long (with the exception of Lubotzky's colloquium talk which lasted one hour). Most of the talks contained surveys of the relevant results in the area and focused on general ideas rather than technical details, which  made them accessible to a broader audience but at the same time provided information about very recent developments. This made the program interesting and valuable to experts as well as to graduate students who attended the workshop. It should be emphasized that the NSF support enabled the organizers to invite 10 graduate students from various US schools.
